job_title: Engineering Specialist in Woodlands New Town,
pros: Lunchtime we normally go in a group or for teabreak but it's optional. It is better to make friends with your colleagues because they will help you. Their system is slowly improving by noting down because in the past they just say once during passdown and you only have that passdown guy to ask from.. Still leaves room for improvement though. There are some politics but just concentrate on your work and be friendly to everyone. They are quite good people but the work gets a little tough sometimes when some of the engineers are demanding..
cons: Starting off it was really bad during the first days several years back. The seniors do not want to teach because they felt it was not their job and they just go on leave leaving you to fend for yourselves. Fortunately, somebody implemented some system to make our lives easier and they make us rotate our duties so the seniors also get to do other work. The new staff came and learned quickly in turn we teach each other and end up we teach each other which is great. It is a highly social place which will be great if you like to talk but talk and learn at the same time because nobody would care about you if you still do not know your stuff. It is quite a proactive job where you learn by asking so do not be afraid to ask. Socializing is very important, don't keep to yourself or be too high profile and doesn't do work.

review_title: Toxic Management, Poor Benefits, No Growth
pros: You get a gym and some decent amenities in the office but those aren't enough to offset the negatives about this place. There's also reimbursement for further studies so make use of that to jump elsewhere if you do plan on staying for a bit.
cons:
No mentorship and guidance given to new staff. There is a mismatch of expectations between management and engineers, so your contributions as an engineer will be either overlooked or used to pad your manager's portfolio. No exposure to other departments or senior management as an individual contributor, which means your career growth and opportunities are limited, unlike the high-flying execs who get promoted or rotated into new roles almost every other year. Rank-and-file staff stay stagnant in their cubicles at the same function for years (and your pay reflects that too).

Hire-and-fire mentality, hence engineering is seen as a cost centre and thus treated like a commodity to be scaled up or down as needed. Which is also why opportunities for engineers to move about are few and far between since the company sees no point in investing in a cost centre. Retrenchments and reorganisations will be on your colleagues' minds most of the time, which makes for a very gloomy atmosphere at work.

Colleagues are generally alright with the exception of those who gossip a lot or contact you outside of work for meaningless issues. Most coworkers are still friendly and helpful but don’t expect a lot of product-specific knowledge transfer since everyone is protective of their portfolios, which affects their ricebowls. People generally keep to themselves here even though company events are conducted from time to time.

Compared to other places I’ve worked at, the onboarding process was done without much thought, and with outdated materials as well. Offboarding was done similarly haphazardly as well, with people contacting me for admin issues even after leaving the company. For what they are worth, HR seems to get more perks than core engineering in Seagate. :)

review_title: A good company that is sinking
job_title: Senior Engineer in Woodlands New Town,
pros:
Its a legacy company. Had been in the market for 30 plus years.
Steve Luczo is great guy, he was the one who brought back the company from rags to the situation it is now. 
Relatively stable employment.
Fair benefits.
Fair employee care.

The core business of company has lost its competitve edge. All these years it had been surviving with minimal profit margin. But now that SSD price are declining, Seagate is in hot soup. It is franctically buying other companies to keep itself afloat.
cons:
Manager is the deciding authority.
Some undesirable managers who grew up the corporate ladder buttering superiors has set a system. They expect the subordinates to kiss their feet, their job will be saved, good appraisal etc.
Skills, expertises are ignored and pleasing the supervisor counts when deployed under these managers.
In general people have become complacent over the years, they are not agile or agressive and hence loosing business to its major competitor and solid storage devices market.
Steve Luczo is great guy, he was the one who brought back the company from rags to the situation it is now. But that does not mean company employees are of good standard.
Singapore division is way to bad and the senior management in Singapore try to keep their jobs and seat by doing plenty of politics.

review_title: Great employer with international colleagues and a supportive management team
pros:
The culture is such that the management listens to the subordinates and ensures that most of its business activities adheres to its mantra, the "Seagate Way".
Seagate also offers constant upgrading of skills and its HR handles their duties efficiently (E.g. pay comes on time, grievances are taken into considerations and medical claims are easily processed)
cons: In my honest opinion, chances of moving up the corporate ladder would be difficult as everyone wants to stay in Seagate hence, no one ever budges. Maybe occasionally depending on the department. Also, it is common for large organizations to have internal job transfers but again depending on your department, your manager who might not want you to leave would not even consider your transfer application!

review_title: Conducive work environment, supportive colleagues and ample development opportunities
pros: If you're looking for learning and development opportunities, this is where you should be. There are plenty of projects around that could help you show off your capabilities and expose you to regional/global work experience. And personally, I think recognition is also easy to come by if you're one of the better performers (at least in my department).
cons:
Employee benefits in general are slightly below what other top MNCs are giving (e.g. no. of days of AL, lack of healthcare coverage for dependants, stock options/RSUs for certain levels, etc)

For certain job functions, an employee tends to have to cover the workload of more than 1 headcount and the arrival of a new headcount to support the extra workload during high volume tends to come too late (by then, employees would have burnt out due to working late too often)

pros:
- Good team environment
- Opportunities to travel (depends highly on department/position however)
- Good work/life balance
 
Overall, a good place to gain good work experience, but probably not a good long-term choice of employer, especially because of the rapid decline of the hard disk industry
cons:
- Some reluctance to accept change
- Management can be inconsistent
- Industry is on a decline making the future highly unpredictable
- Slow promotions and poor AWS, pay adjustments (sometimes even frozen when financial climate is bad)
- Much of the technology is just "ported over" from USA... there is definitely an "us" and "them" mentality, and a 'god' complex towards USA sites

pros:
- Generally relax work environment 
- Friendly colleagues
- Good office building and location
cons:
- Low morale
- Terrible middle management - no accountability, no skills to motivate their own people, no clue how to manage projects systematically (some of them are a complete mess)
- Questionable direction from exec team - complete denial that ssd is a viable threat, even though business is shrinking, constant brainwashing at all hands meetings
- Too many people adding no value to company’s products
- Very limited opportunity for career progression 
- Old timer management are too rigid, arrogant, ignorant
- Politics is getting worse as the company shrinks and certain people are becoming protective

pros: Work environment is relatively good and still with decent people trying to make the best of the situation
cons:
Seagate cannot seem to be able to handle acquisition and mergers at all. Every M&A is a failure and then company is impacted

Denial about solid state and upcoming rival technologies. Seagate is failing to address all these leading to a definitely shrinking revenue. A slow and steady slide down.

With the changes to the IT leadership, it is now all about achieving targets. So the work environment is now about self survival and has become toxic and political. No hesitation to throw someone else under the bus for their own benefit

review_title: Good place to work for, but there may be no future
pros:
- Good place to start first job, because it's a global scale company so you can learn many things not limited to your job field only, and many chances exist as well.
- Work-life balance. (No overtime work)
- Good colleagues.
- Only two major companies exist in HDD business (WD, Seagate)
cons:
- You know HDD is at risk. There may be no future at the end.
- I think there are too many politicians more than engineers, real workers.
- Salary increase is much less than expected. (Do not expect unless you are at something Senior+, Staff+, Manager+, Director+)
- Now Seagate is minimizing all the costs from production, less important R&D (something like B2C), non R&D
- Layoff at least every 6 months

pros: Flexible working hours, nice building and facilities, free dinner if work late
cons:
_ Shrinking industry, heavy office politics, frozen or slow promotion & little pay increment & bonus due to on-going re-structure plan. 
_ The direction is ambiguous. Many failed business acquisition damaged company finance heavily. As a result, employees became doubtful about company's future and top management's decision.
 _ Old tech company, old employees. Average age is close to 40. "Younger" people tends to stay at office quite late. Don't come here if you haven't got marriage or girlfriend yet.

review_title: Science Park 1 R&D - Work is manageable and comfortable but don't expect good $$ and little job security
pros:
Once you get used to the life there, it is comfortable, and routine. 
Managers are understanding and flexible.
If you just want to bring home your salary every month and don't wish for too much changes or disruption, this is  the right place for you.
cons:
Little job security. Seagate is infamous for restructuring and retrenchment.
Don't expect good pay or bonuses.
No job rotation. Some people are still doing the same specialized jobs for close to 15 years or even more. This should be a good point for those wanting to retire but a bad point for those who have the "drive" in them.

review_title: Seagate working environment, in Seagate Science Park, Singapore
pros:
- Very flexible working hours environment, you could almost come to office at any time as long as you fulfill your responsibility. 
- Overtime work got support with food and taxi claim. 
- Very friendly working environment, no hierarchy in the management. 
- A lot of things to learn (if you want), from code development to Matlab, firmware ...
- Good documentation in technical so that you can easy to learn by yourself if you are persistent enough.
cons:
- Sometimes too many failure and analysis process may prevent you from research and development and self development. 
- The pay is not just so so comparable to outside market. 
- Pay raise also very nominal, promotion while is quite slow.

review_title: Not a good place for fresh graduate
job_title: Process Engineer in Woodlands New Town,
pros:
- If you want a retirement life,  this is the place to be 
- Pace is relatively slow 
- Colleagues are friendly and helpful 
- Even, engineers have OT pay, flat rate $18/hour, which is lower than normal working hour rate
cons:
- Package is not competitive, fringe benefit is very low
- Multiple force leaves that deduct your AL 
- Not much career progression
- Company is not growing in general 
- Process engineer need to be almost 24/7 on call, although not required to go back to plant, but need to response with multi Whatapps chat

job_title: Engineering Specialist in Woodlands New Town,
pros:
As an associate Engineer aka Engineering Specialist , you are only tasked with execution and implementation. 
Stress-free , friendly environment, my supervisor has no race bias but some do. Fairly acceptable remuneration
cons:
You stay too long you loose all your career ambition and it becomes all about doing OT and earning a living.

There is no proper screening of employees, some with Bachelor of Arts degree from India also join as Associate Engineer because of recommendation. The guy driving forklift in Malaysia also join as Associate Engineer because of recommendation. Some supervisors are under qualified because they are old timers, just NITEC cert, but managing staff with poly engineering diplomas, so they are forever scared of ambitious hardworking qualified personal. This kind of supervisors appreciate and promote low qualified Malaysian friends to keep a buffer around them since they themselves are Malaysian or former Malaysian. 
You can see people from Penang / Perak has a strong most in Seagate Woodlands but some of them are really well qualified but some just pull strings to stay on.

S-pass holders come in with basic pay of $2,850 because of the minimum pay requirement set by MOM for S-pass. But Singaporeans and PRs who are in the company for almost a decade doing the same tasks as the newcomer S-pass holders are still on the journey to hit $2,850 since they started below $2,000 as fresh graduates. 

When you join there is no classroom training, as they put it " monkey see, monkey do" , there is no strict adherence of SOP because there is practically none. If you are looking for a career, stay away, if you are looking for a job then join.

cons:

Sometime if business are not doing well, we may not have any increment.

pros: Don't often get calls outside of office hours. onsite gym, good canteen, most employees are treated with respect and there is a good sense of being part of a team.
cons: A lingering uncertainty about the business - used as an excuse to block promotions and payrises when downturn cycles hit. Aging management structure - mostly all over 50 with no opportunity to go into senior roles for anyone else. Definitely still stuck in the corporate boardroom culture of the 1990s. Directors often crack terrible "dad jokes" while engineers give presentations for example. Flexible working - max 20% of your time at home. A lot of jobs can be done from home. Most jobs are still metrics focused/obsessed. Things like chasing single wafer scrap is a waste of time. Yet the yield team pride themselves on pretending that we can assign a root cause to every scrap issue.

review_title: Above Average Culture, Below Average Compenation
pros: Seagate is a good company to work for. The work-life balance is great, and the teams I have been on have been my motivation to stay. Many employees have been there 10+ years, and that has something to say about the values of the company.
cons:
Compensation is way below par. There are smaller companies that will pay almost double for the same position and rank. This shows not only financially, but also in the average level of talent of engineers. There are some great engineers at the company but the overall average skill level is pretty poor, putting a lot more pressure on the better engineers to perform past their limits to keep things moving.

There is also a very big value on company politics at the senior management levels. A lot of decisions are made to make the next guy up the latter happy rather than making the work of the engineers easier or more efficient.

pros: 1) .No one comes to office - They come to office once a month and for a few hours . 2). Every 5 Min. Job response would take them 1 Week . Since most of the times they 'd be unavailable. 3). No clear KRA or expectations - They 'd ask for work on daily basis like a day wage earner.
cons: 1) Politics - Heavy politics - Cheap & not letting a new commer settle down . 2) No handovers - You need to create from scratch . However, Everyone will tell you stories about " what happened in the past " however , You 'll never find any material related to it . 3). Refrence teams - All teams are hired via refrences only & hence they are quite thick with each other in creating chaos & misleading. 4). Dangerous for women - Women are not safe , They are used and abused . There is high degree of sexual harrasment. 5). No work timming - While you are expected to be available on the country time . At the same time you are also expected to be available at US & Other market times ( US due to HO and Regional head office time . Means , You'd never get time off . 6) Toxic culture - Zero integrity & No honesty & No trust toxic culture . You are always at the mercy of your manager. Most people here don't care about the work or the company . They care about their personal side incomes . 7) Random Jobs - They will give you anything or everything that your profile has been hired for . Although, they have people to do the job - however, They'd overburden a new commer with all department jobs they are friends with . 8) Year to just figure your job and expectations - it might take you a year to figure what the company expects from your profile . 9) The company would not give your any bonus or appraisal, If your manager doesn't approve of you . And your manager won't approve of you , If you are doing some good work and fixing things . 10) It's a usual practice to abuse and yell at people for hours . Most heads in the office sit with their legs and shoes on the table where the laptop is placed . 11) Women are only hired as eye candy in the teams and for managers to call for hours and speak to them as entertainment options . Be ware .

job_title: Staff Process Engineer in Londonderry County Borough, Northern Ireland
pros:
Cutting edge technology
Great people. Friendly atmosphere. 
Training opportunities available.
cons:
Salary not at all competitive compared to similar companies on both sides of the border. 
Senior management completely out of touch with the needs of their engineering staff. 
No trust placed in the staff who performed beyond all expectations working from home throughout the pandemic. 
No flexibility now being offered post pandemic despite production metrics operating at all time highs.
Promotion and career progression very limited.
This is now turning into a company where people come for a few years to get experience on their CV and then move on to better opportunities/better pay. And rightly so. With more flexibility being offered all over the country and needless to say better compensation, talented people should avoid this place like the plague as it’s a dead end. Senior management are cowards who toe the party line from America. They have no interest in doing the right thing by their people who have been loyal to the company for decades. They had a great opportunity to provide engineering staff with a flexible workweek with the option of working from home a few days a week. Instead they went for the shortsighted option as usual spouting some nonsense about not being collaborative enough from home. Ridiculous carry on. This company is only going to attract poor engineering staff from here on, and they only have themselves to blame.

review_title: Not a good company to work with
pros:
- Good Managers (If you are lucky)
- Latest tools and technologies
- Subsidised Transport
- Annual Hike and Bonus
- Less Politics on low levels
cons:
The saying "Employees leave their manager but not the organisation" is not applicable here. I was in Seagate for my manager and left for HR policies and company culture.

It's not an employee centric organisation, below are few points to support the statement. In future, it will have hard time to attract good talents.

- No work from home kit provided during COVID
- Hesitation to send laptop during COVID if it gets faulty
- Sick Leave: Need to attach medical certificate even for a single day of leave (Never seen this in any organisation)
- Causal Leave: This can not fall in between public holiday and annual leave. (Seriously! This is the trust?)
- Sudden increase of notice period to 90 days for existing employees without any acknowledgement. 
- Less pay more work
- Slow and cheap laptop/hardware where other product companies give choice
- Not enough awards and recognition to keep employees motivated
- Status call on late evenings

job_title: Senior Staff Program/Project Manager in Shakopee, MN
pros:
Seagate’s values of Integrity, Innovation and Inclusion are not just something you see on the website, but are embedded in the culture. Leadership led meetings tie back information to the values. Seagate actively pursues sustainability and circularity with products, pulling back drives to refurbish or at a minimum, reclaim precious materials. I feel that I know how I contribute to the broader picture and communication from leadership is timely.
I feel that Seagate’s Covid response she has been on point. This is a fluid time and they haven’t acted rashly but rather try to do what is right for employees while being lawfully compliant. This is not easy as a global company managing hundred of jurisdictions.
cons: I wish there had been some more tangible help than a $25 dollar per month expense option for Covid. I ended up purchasing $500 of hardware to furnish my home office and at $25 per month it didn’t really feel worth my time to expense. I’m still looking for a decent chair for working at home.

review_title: great place to retire while still collecting a paycheck
pros: Interesting work, fast paced, challenging work.
cons:
Company is top-heavy, lots of directors reporting to directors reporting to directors. There's a lack of accountability in management so deadwood just sticks around and collects a paycheck until they retire. Promotion and equity opportunity for younger professionals is impacted by this. Equity awards are largely based upon grade level, lots of equity awards going to useless directors that are just sitting around collecting a paycheck instead of the young talent. Company policy allows equity awards to young professionals but most VPs in the company don't have the courage to spread out the equity awards, instead they give all the awards to their direct reports and other boot lickers in the company. Company is hiring a few lower skilled workers, but tends to trim disproportionately from the bottom when doing RIFS, further exacerbating the top-heavy structure. 

Promotions are made mainly based on individual success or to retain good individual contributors, not necessarily based on a person's leadership skills, as a result there are a lot of poor leaders in leadership positions with no real training structure to improve their leadership skills, it's really up to individuals and their direct managers to identify a training regiment. There's no formal 360 degree feedback program so dysfunctional managers are running open loop.

review_title: Struggling with a Military Mindset in HR

cons: Military mindset, unable to attract and retain young talent. Many in leadership have been at Seagate 20+ years. Often quoted by younger members as a "boomer" company. Compensation is lagging, the company is working to reduce our flexibility, leadership unable to connect with younger employees who value creativity and flexibility. The CEO has a "don't let the door hit you on the way out" mentality.

job_title: Senior Engineer in Londonderry County Borough, Northern Ireland
pros: relaxed environment, nice and helpful colleagues
cons: Dead slow promotion. I have seen people working in senior roles for over 8 years now, thats too much. There is a balance point between working in a relaxed environment and trying to get career growth. Zero career growth here. I no longer want to work in a relaxed environment, I rather want to move up the professional ladder and work more. Lots of people here with this mentality i.e. they are just after a relaxed life and wont care too much about their career growths. Most of the time, the bonuses etc are all depending on how your manager sees your work, it doesn't seem to be strictly performance based increase, rather a set increase on how the managers perceive you. Its a good place for a training after your university degree but certainly less paid compared to market trends. getting to a Senior Staff can take about 13 or 14 years if you start as a Senior Engineer, unless you are very lucky. Managers appear to care about your professional development but there is nothing tangible, I requested for training and development opportunities a number of times but each time it was not entertained. This triggered me to look for opportunities elsewhere. Advice to young people is to constantly keep on looking for new opportunities and keep on interviewing.

review_title: Inclusive Employee Focused and Ethical Company
pros:
Walks the talk when it comes to caring about its employees. Offers employees the opportunity to seek out new career opportunities. Works with employees to retrain them for new growth areas Vs the typical hire and fire process used by most other high-tech companies.

The Seagate culture is to focus on long term shareholder growth and to do it ethically. I have worked for 8 fortune 500 high tech companies in my three decades of high-tech employment and this is the only company that comes close to doing it right. Seagate has proved to me that a corporation can make money (a lot of it) without black mailing their customers, trashing their suppliers and treating their employees and the local communities as a disposable asset. If you are feed up with working in that kind of environment, you might want to look at Seagate.
cons: For the most part everyone at Seagate works hard. Perhaps too hard. Seagate is a worldwide corporation and depending on your assignment you may find yourself working at all hours of the day. With team members in China, India Colo and Cal the sun never sets on Seagate. Managing work life balance can be challenging.

review_title: Badly harassed and bulled by other employee
job_title: Senior RnD Engineer in Derry, Northern Ireland
pros:
- Good technology, probably one of the most impressive technologies you might ever cross in your career. I have personally learned a lot and this has been a key piece in my career to transit from University/postdoc into the industry.
- Seagate encourages a nice and friendly environment with absolutely no blaming atmosphere (unless you are surrounded by toxic people -- that's my case)
- You may find great people, in general managers are friendly and like they enjoy talking with employees. Most of managers have a human behaviour to the employees and care about their wellness.
- In general, Seagate is setup on a way that you do not feel hierarchy, most of the times (unless you get a limiting manager). If you get a good innovative idea, you may get listened and your idea will be strongly supported (unless there is a toxic, jealous and reactive employee around you obsessed to stop your growth)
- Most of the times you are surrounded by pro-active people willing to strongly support your idea and give as many resources as they can. Personally in my case, I got a nice mentorship by somebody who was fully committed with my success.
- People with really good critical thinking skills willing to test your ideas.
- I found that if you are at the right project and you work hard, you have a bright future in the company since Seagate offers you many opportunities as long as you are a pro-active person.
- Relaxed work-environment (this might be also a bad thing as described in "Cons" section)
- During COVID they have taken a really human and appropriate approach.
- Personally, I think they pay is good since Derry/Londonderry's cost of life is low.
- Seagate in Northern Ireland is recently doing a lot to improve. (in the theory, for see how it goes in the practise, read below)
cons:
Despite many advantages of working in Seagate and the fact that I recognize that most of people are great here, I have personally got so many bad experiences that has pushed me to leave the company in a bad mental health situation. The reasons are:
- I have got badly harassed from an employee since the beginning. The reason, he was a "career-stagnated" employee who gets jealous when new employees join the company and start to "shine". Thus, these new employees might get promotion before the "failing and stagnated" employee, then that employee will harass and make bullying to the new starts. Personally, I have got harassed during 2 years, until I ended up in burn out and depression.
- The harassment has been in many ways, trying to exclude from meetings and projects, verbally violent, blaming, physically violent as well (once thought I was going to get punched in the office) and has also sabotaged my work (personally once this employee has "probably" manually scratched my experiments/devices in order to make them un-usable and then needed to scrap my work).
- In addition, all the time felt that person stand behind my screen looking at what I am doing and trying to continuously "dirtily" compete by copying my ideas, doing things in parallel instead of collaborating in order to "win the competition" (which does not really exist) and hiding information to the others or create fake data and results when not getting the right data to compete.
- 80% of the time spent dealing with harassment and defending myself since the manager never solved the issue, 20% of the time spent doing engineering jobs. -- Personally, I have seen new starters, smart people, come to Seagate with a brilliant future, and their careers got completely pushed out by this person who just sneaks in their projects and violently pushes them out.
- My manager had many chances to solve the issue since I communicated to him many times, however his actions were really vague. And most of the times he was bringing back the issue by, instead of separating me from that problematic employee, bringing him once and once again to the projects where I was working on.
- My manager, despite the severe harassment issues, always discouraged me to report the issue to HR. I asked him several time to report to HR, but never wanted and came with sentences like "if you report to HR this will have bad consequences and blablabla...".
- This makes me thing my manager might be more worried that everyone could be aware there is a problem in his team rather than really taking care that employees work effectively and they do not harass each other.

- Another bad experience in Seagate, that is a minor reason for leaving but also important, is that in 8 months I haven't basically got any motivating work to do. Just got projects without any real reason "to be" or any utility which just got cancelled weeks later. This contributes also to the employee to feel meaningless in the company and pushes employees to leave. -- This is also a reason why Seagate can stagnate your career if you fall on a "nothing to do" blackhole.

review_title: Frequent Layoffs, Clique-ish Management, People Politics
pros: Generally nice coworkers, decent office with amenities (gym, outdoor BBQ space, recreation room, etc.), stock purchase discount and ability to claim reimbursement for further studies (subject to management approval, of course).
cons:
Rank and file employees have virtually no visibility over company direction in terms of future products and especially personnel movement or reorganizations. Being in product development feels directionless with uncertain roadmaps and a lack of solid products to work on in the Singapore R&D center. Layoffs are also frequent, especially in 2020 when Covid struck, and colleagues were only informed near their last day with the company. Totally no transparency at all. Company still did alright and could afford to give high bonuses to shareholders and executives but if you aren't in the old boys' club you will always have to face constant restructuring and job uncertainty every year. Needless to say, general morale isn't good in there with many long-serving senior employees waiting for the inevitable to come.

No job mobility, and letting your manager know that you are interested in an open internal position is a red flag to your job security. Management claims to encourage mobility and reskilling into growth areas but does little to support your career growth. Loosing a subordinate through an internal transfer would jeopardize your manager's portfolio since their team would shrink, so they would put you up for layoff or give you a poor rating to justify letting you go so that they have a reason to bring in a fresh hire. Pay is also not competitive with market levels. Internal politics due to different teams wanting to keep their rice bowls means that knowledge transfer is few and far between. No work recognition at all and favoritism is oftentimes practiced, which means opportunities to grow and exposure to different roles and projects will not be shared equally if you are not in on it.

Job progression is slow, and could be slower depending on your team and how vital the company views your work. Staying here for long would mean losing out to the general tech market rate and even losing out to the starting salaries of fresh grads. For young folks joining this company, stay for the experience of working in an established, but legacy, tech MNC but keep your skills and knowledge about the current tech stack current so that you can jump when better opportunities arise.

The lack of career and product visibility is made worse by the banning of TheLayoff.com and Glassdoor in the internal network (at least when I was in there), which should speak volumes about how Seagate treats feedback and complaints, whether they be genuine or not. People generally keep quiet about their misgivings for fear of offending someone with authority or influence who can easily crush their rice bowls.

review_title: Seagate, Just wait for the end of the shakeout.
job_title: Technical Writer/Editor in Scotts Valley, CA
pros: In Santa Cruz County, CA, Seagate is a large corporate employer with decent benefits; and a definite plus was not driving over the hill to work.  The non-management people, in general, are dedicated and loyal employees, and work together well.  Many of the managers also work together well and support their work groups.  Pay rates are competitive with the rates for large companies over the hill in Silicon Valley.  Upgrades to the Scotts Valley site included building of an on-site Cafe/restaurant which is much enjoyed by all as the food is good and is reasonably priced.  Seagate also works with local non-profit organizations and CSA (Community Supported Agriculture), and provides opportunities for employees to help support charitable organizations. Seagate also donates money to these organizations.
cons: The Scotts Valley site is a corporate business location and as such the job titles most unaffected by economic downturns are Account Management (supports Sales and Customers), Order Management (processes Customer Orders), and Upper Management (work with Customers, Sales, Strategic Planning).  During the recent downturn all other departments were subject to RIF (Reduction in Force).  The Disc Drive Industry is very immediately affected by downturns and the survivors are the companies that are running a 'tight ship'.  Seagate has been Vice President (top management) heavy for a very long time.  A top heavy management structure does not respond as quickly to economic conditions in the market place in the way a more lean organization is able to do.

pros:
I was given the opportunity to learn and grow into a role within the organization. Seagate's tendency to promote internally allowed for that and I appreciate the opportunity greatly. There's high respect for peers within Seagate, with mixed respect from managers depending on the manager. I had a great couple of managers. 

The work/life balance was nice including a general ability to take time in the middle of the day to run a personal errand or something similar. The benefits were average, except for the employee stock purchase plan which was exceptional while I was there.

The company is very entrenched into its market. That can make for a reliable job. The technology is aging, but Seagate management is very forward looking and I imagine will continue to adapt to the upcoming changing technologies in digital storage.
cons: There was a lot of meetings for meetings sake, which I think comes from everyone wanting to be involved in exciting stuff. Although there wasn't always enough exciting stuff to go around, there was plenty of "tactical" work, or mundane repetitive process work for everyone. There's a lot of room for improvement in cross functional automation and internal processes.

cons: Constant change, some change is needed but there is too much there. Poor leadership being hired in that don't know what they are doing. Lots of really bad decisions being made overall. review_title: Don't get too attached to your job.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Scotts Valley, CA
pros: Seagte is one of the largest and best paying employers in Santa Cruz County.  The benefits are very good as compared to most employers in the county, and comparable to most other large companies in nearby Silicon Valley.  When the economy isn't crumbling and there are no lay offs in the foresable future, there does tend to be room for career growth and movement within the company.
cons: Seagate is moving most of their functions to Asia.  While not making an public announcement of it, the "understood" plan is that within a three to five year time frame, the company will have only a sales force and limited executive presence in the US.  That idea does not make for much job security within the company and most people are stressed about losing their jobs as they watch the folks around them get outsourced. Steve Luczo wrote a company wide email about how he "loves" Seagate and how he thinks of Seagate as a family and how we should treat each other like family.....in my case I got that email the same say I go the news that my positioned was being outsourced to Asia and I had three months to stay and trail my own replacement.  If I didn't stay, I would not be eligible for my severance package.  Not very family like if you ask me.

review_title: Great company. Fantastic work environment. Loses steam in all area in recent years.
pros: The company pay their staff well compared with similar companies in the storage industries. Good working environment with sound HR policies with comprehensive health care coverage including adoption assistance & higher education subsidies. Design engineering site in Minnesota, Colorado, California and even Singapore provide opportunities within org. Factory sites in Thailand, Singapore, Malaysia & China provide further opportunities for job growth beyond home ground if you are willing. Good expat incentives for Director & above only.
cons:
This is a vertically integrated company. It held an impressive portfolio of technologies and IPs. There were sufficient talent pools within the company to ensure it is always number one. However, the huge downside is management is too top heavy. Too many VPs, Exec Directors, Senior Directors & Directors making decisions focusing on their own turfs and poor execution of products led to losing it's number one position in recent years. Initial management changes implemented by Former but now CEO again Steve Luzos in 2004 was sound  with sound long term strategies but ran by the same old veterans who get the company in trouble in the first place in 1990s.

Morale is low with recent layoffs. Engineers (likely pay check to pay check) discouraged with across the board 10% wage cuts. Upper management more cuts but were cushioned by company's generous stock options and other bonuses.

review_title: Dot Hill/Cloud Systems group is the place to be
pros: Formerly Dot Hill, the Cloud Systems group is doing some amazing work in storage tech. The people are phenomenally talented and intelligent. The middle management is excellent. This creates great work, keeps the pressure off for deadlines. Very worker friendly policies such as flexible times, working from home and unlimited PTO. Good benefits - 401k, bonuses. Restricted Stock and ESPP generates a lot of wealth quite fast.
cons:
* They got better as I left but product releases very crazy chaotic.

* Seagate taking over Dot Hill did a lot of good things to the stock and benefits but really messed up the small company nature.

* We survived for several years and rode out recessions without laying off anyone but Seagate came in and laid off beloved and veteran employees just for their bottom line. We  went from family to anyone is replaceable in 1 year.

* Open recs never get filled. Upper management knows that they can squeeze more out of engineers and force middle management to keep chugging along with what they get. I honestly feel bad for some of them.

* It's tiring to play second fiddle to the drive department which is always ailing and doing poorly. The Cloud Systems group is profitable but has to bear layoff costs when the rest of the company struggles.

review_title: Seagate used to be a great place to work at
job_title: Engineering Technician in Oklahoma City, OK
pros:
- Good hourly pay
- Wonderful co-workers
cons:
This company used to treat its employees well and with respect. This has been in a gradual decline over the last few years, and the family sense one used to feel when coming into work has long since disappeared.
- No flexibility, rather rigid and old-fashioned work environment
- Working at Seagate used to be about openness. That's no longer the case, and where all ideas were welcome in the past, one gets the sense that this is no longer so
- Indiscriminate lay-offs. I'm not 100% certain, but it seems that people were let go according to pay grade, not lack of contribution. Also, it'd be great to take volunteers for lay-offs, instead of letting people go who really still want to stay with Seagate
